verses.verse: (Ezra 9:13; (Jer. 17:21)) Did not your fathers do thus, and did not our God bring all this disaster on us and on this city? Yet you bring added wrath on Israel by profaning the Sabbath.”

So it was, at the gates of Jerusalem, as it (Lev. 23:32) began to be dark before the Sabbath, that I commanded the gates to be shut, and charged that they must not be opened till after the Sabbath. (Jer. 17:21, 22) Then I posted some of my servants at the gates, so that no burdens would be brought in on the Sabbath day.
Now the merchants and sellers of all kinds of wares lodged outside Jerusalem once or twice.
Then I warned them, and said to them, “Why do you spend the night around the wall? If you do so again, I will lay hands on you!” From that time on they came no more on the Sabbath.

And I commanded the Levites that (1 Chr. 15:12; Neh. 12:30) they should cleanse themselves, and that they should go and guard the gates, to sanctify the Sabbath day. Remember me, O my God, concerning this also, and spare me according to the greatness of Your mercy!
In those days I also saw Jews who ((Ex. 34:16; Deut. 7:3, 4); Ezra 9:2; Neh. 10:30) had married women of (Neh. 4:7) Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.
And half of their children spoke the language of Ashdod, and could not speak the language of Judah, but spoke according to the language of one or the other people.

So I (Prov. 28:4) contended with them and cursed them, struck some of them and pulled out their hair, and made them (Ezra 10:5; Neh. 10:29, 30) swear by God, saying, “You shall not give your daughters as wives to their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons or yourselves.

(1 Kin. 11:1, 2) Did not Solomon king of Israel sin by these things? Yet among many nations there was no king like him, (2 Sam. 12:24, 25) who was beloved of his God; and God made him king over all Israel. (1 Kin. 11:4-8) Nevertheless pagan women caused even him to sin.
Should we then hear of your doing all this great evil, ((Ezra 10:2); Neh. 13:23) transgressing against our God by marrying pagan women?”
And one of the sons (Neh. 12:10, 12) of Joiada, the son of Eliashib the high priest, was a son-in-law of (Neh. 4:1, 7; 6:1, 2) Sanballat the Horonite; therefore I drove him from me.
(Neh. 6:14) Remember them, O my God, because they have defiled the priesthood and (Mal. 2:4, 11, 12) the covenant of the priesthood and the Levites.
(Neh. 10:30) Thus I cleansed them of everything pagan. I also (Neh. 12:1) assigned duties to the priests and the Levites, each to his service,
and to bringing (Neh. 10:34) the wood offering and the firstfruits at appointed times. (Neh. 13:14, 22) Remember me, O my God, for good!

(The King Dethrones Queen Vashti) Now it came to pass in the days of (Ezra 4:6; Dan. 9:1) Ahasuerus (this was the Ahasuerus who reigned (Esth. 8:9) over one hundred and twenty-seven provinces, (Dan. 6:1) from India to Ethiopia),
in those days when King Ahasuerus (1 Kin. 1:46) sat on the throne of his kingdom, which was in (Neh. 1:1; Dan. 8:2) Shushan the citadel,

that in the third year of his reign he (Gen. 40:20; Esth. 2:18) made a feast for all his officials and servants—the powers of Persia and Media, the nobles, and the princes of the provinces being before him—
when he showed the riches of his glorious kingdom and the splendor of his excellent majesty for many days, one hundred and eighty days in all.

And when these days were completed, the king made a feast lasting seven days for all the people who were present in Shushan the citadel, from great to small, in the court of the garden of the king’s palace.

There were white and blue linen curtains fastened with cords of fine linen and purple on silver rods and marble pillars; and the (Esth. 7:8; Ezek. 23:41; Amos 2:8; 6:4) couches were of gold and silver on a mosaic pavement of alabaster, turquoise, and white and black marble.
And they served drinks in golden vessels, each vessel being different from the other, with royal wine in abundance, (Esth. 2:18) according to the generosity of the king.
In accordance with the law, the drinking was not compulsory; for so the king had ordered all the officers of his household, that they should do according to each man’s pleasure.
